fields.descriptive_line: Hand coloured paper on linen game, The Mansion of Bliss, published in England by William Darton in 1822
fields.physical_description:
Design: etching, coloured by hand, 12 sections mounted on linen, showing 34 medallions. representing good and bad moral characteristics
No. of squares: 34
Squares illustrated: all
Square numbering: all
Squares titled: in booklet
Subject of starting square: Innocent amusement
Subject of ending square: Mansion of Bliss
fields.title: The Mansion of Bliss; A New Game for the Amusement of Youth
fields.public_access_description:
The full title of this game includes the line: 'designed for the amusement of youth with a view to promote the progressive improvement of the juvenile mind and to deter then from pursuing the dangerous paths of vice'. 

The game has 34 playing spaces which are named for virtues such as Good Example and Obedience to Parents, and vices such as Robbing Orchards and Cruelty to Animals. The players begin on the first space,  Innocent Amusement and the winner is the first to land on the last space: the Mansion of Bliss. The rules of the game are presented in rhyming verse.
fields.history_note:
The rules are written in four line verse.
Full Title includes - designed for the amusement of youth with a view to promote the progressive improvement of the juvenile mind and to deter then from pursuing the dangerous paths of vice.
fields.historical_context_note:
Rewards: receipt of counters, forward movement and extra turns
Forfeits: payment of counters, backward movement, missing turns
No. of Players: 2 to 12 
Equipment required: teetotum, markers and counters (12 each)

Rules:
THE NEW GAME OF THE MANSION OF BLISS IN VERSE BY THO. NEWTON. LONDON WILLIAM  DARTON 58 HOLBORN HILL 1822

RULES FOR PLAYING
This game is played with a tetotum (spelling) marked 1,2,3,4; and any number of persons, from two to twelve, may join in the amusement.
Each player must be provided with twelve counters and a mark; each mark varying in colour, that every one may know their own.
Before they begin, each player must deposit four counters into the back.
When it has been agreed who shall begin the game, the first person, having spun the Tetotum, must place his mark upon the number corresponding with that the Tetotum presents uppermost.  If a 1 turn up, he must place his mark upon Innocent Amusement, which the rule in the verse directs him to turn the tetotum again  If  he should turn up a 3 the next turn, he must place his mark three numbers forward, which will be Bridewell, which verse directs him to remain there while every other player turns the tetotum three times.
If any player be sent back, he must not act according to the direction of that figure he must only go by the directions of the figure he last spun from; nor must he, if he be directed to advance to any figure, act according to the directions of that figure; but must only go by the directions of the figure he last spun.
If any player should turn up a number which would carry him beyond the Mansion of Bliss as many numbers as he turns beyond it, so many he must place his mark back from the figure he spun from;  viz. if his mark be on False Friendship, and he should turn up a 3, he then will have spun 1 beyond the game, therefore he must  place his mark back upon the Ship which is 1 behind the figure he turned from, where he must remain till his turn comes again.

DIRECTIONS
1.  Innocent Amusement;  2.  Precipitation;  3.  Adversity;  4.  Bridewell;  5.  Good Example;  6.  Negligent Shepherd;  7.  Brotherly Love;  8.  Herd of Swine;  9.  The Peace-Maker;  10.  Fighting;  11.  The School;  12.  Cruelty To Animals;  
13.  Humanity;  14.  Robbing Orchards;  15.  Obedience to Parents;  16.  Prodigal Son;  17.  Repentant Prodigal;  18.  Taking Birds' Nests;  19.  Charity;  20.  The Truant;  21.  The Sailor;  22.  Swearing;  23.  The Blind Man;  24.  The Gamester;  25.  Fidelity;  26.  The Mimic;  27.  Purity;  28.  The Detractor;  29.  Filial Duty;  
30.  Danger of Temptation;  31.  The Ship;  32.  False Friendship;  33.  The Disappointment.;  34.  The Mansion of Bliss.

Each is accompanied with a four line verse giving the rewards or forfeits.

The booklet also contains a list of books and other juvenile works published by William Darton.

Rules placement: booklet
